data.author: Chris Lalancette
data.message:
Force pybind11 to find Python 3. (#15)

We've had sporadic reports of failures to build rclpy because it
can't find Python.h.  It turns out that the problem is that,
by default, pybind11 seems to prefer the Python 2 set of libraries
if the development packages are installed.

This change adds in a CMake extras file that forces pybind11 to
always choose Python 3, even if the Python 2 development libraries
are available.

Signed-off-by: Chris Lalancette <clalancette@openrobotics.org>

data.author: Steven! Ragnarök
data.message:
Update to pybind11 2.9.1.

This appears to be necessary for python_orocos_kdl_vendor.
When forcing the vendor package to build pybind11 prior to this change the following error is present:
    -- pybind11 found, building against installed version
    CMake Error at /home/jenkins-agent/workspace/ci_linux/ws/install/pybind11_vendor/share/cmake/pybind11/pybind11NewTools.cmake:196 (python3_add_library):
      Unknown CMake command "python3_add_library".
    Call Stack (most recent call first):
      /home/jenkins-agent/workspace/ci_linux/ws/build/python_orocos_kdl_vendor/_deps/python_orocos_kdl-src/python_orocos_kdl/CMakeLists.txt:60 (pybind11_add_module)

    -- Configuring incomplete, errors occurred!
    See also "/home/jenkins-agent/workspace/ci_linux/ws/build/python_orocos_kdl_vendor/CMakeFiles/CMakeOutput.log".

The patch from 2.7.1 didn't apply cleanly.
This patch was generated from v2.9.1 after manually creating the changes using the following command:
    git format-patch v2.9.1 --minimal --stdout | \
    awk '/^diff/ { start = 1 } start { if ($0 ~ /^-- $/){ exit(0)}; print $0 }'

data.author: Steven! Ragnarök
data.message: Rename patch file for history continuity.

data.author: Chris Lalancette
data.message:
Update pybind11 to 2.7.1. (#10)

* Update pybind11 to 2.7.1.

This is the version that is shipped in Ubuntu 22.04.
While we are in here, also make it so we only build pybind11
if we need it.
